SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Craburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name MRS. JOHN C. KNAUS.

Present Address ATTICA, SASK.

Pioneer Address McGUIRE, SASK.

Year you came to Saskatchewan 1906.

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 9 in walking distance.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 2

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? About twice a month.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Both days.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Most of our visiting in those days were without invitation.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Generally in the afternoon.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? It was almost impossible to have anywhere without having a meal with your host or hostess.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) In our home it was: "Set in and have a snack."

American settlers said: "Have some dinner or supper."

English settlers said: "Do have some tea with us!"

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Doughnuts or sponge cake + ginger ale (home made) or tea & coffee.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? At first the whole family went as there wasn't much work to do after church and there wasn't much driving.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

The men had to work together to get the building done.

The women had quilting bees to supply the priest's house or some poor family in need. In case of sickness neighbors got together to help any way they could.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Yes, people were anxious to get acquainted and also dispel some of their loneliness and social evenings.

Card parties & dances were often held in each other's homes.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. By 1911-1912 these recreations were not so prevalent.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? The general scheme in the early days was to hold surprise parties where the host & hostess knew nothing about it until the visitors arrived.

8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

As soon as the school was completed it was used for nearly all community activities—meetings, dances, socials, picnics, etc., from 1918 to the present time—1959.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

All our social activities except neighborly visits, centred around the school.

9. When was your first community hall built? School is still used.

What material was it made of? lumber How large was it? about 28 x 36.

Who built it—the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? The community through taxes.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.)

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? No

How were babies and small children provided for? Generally the older children stayed with them. In case of young couples with one or 2 children they took them along.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? Hay bales were tied in a bluff—blanketed some times—sometimes not.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Euchre, Cider and Forty-five.

Was there card playing for a prize? Sometimes.

What dances were popular? Quadrilles, waltzes, two steps.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Not that I know of.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

There was no fuss made.

9. When was your first community hall built? Describe its size and use.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

12. Was there ever any disrepancy between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?

I think this "swank" was more pronounced in small towns than now. When I was going to high school in Lanigan in 1915 the above custom was still done by young ladies.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community?

Not much—generally there was a fun dance given at every wedding.

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Some of the games I remember at the pioneer parties were "Cat & Mouse", "Jacob & Rachel", Blind Man's Buff and tricks with broomsticks, chains, etc.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

The Church and then the schools.

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

1907—also there was a farmer organization called United Grain Growers but I can't recall the year.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

I was too young to know these details but got the impression the farmers were not being treated fairly.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

About 75%.

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

They set up a store in Lanigan which went on the rocks about 1921 or 22.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? No

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people living in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

Box socials, dances, picnics, raffles.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

In the school.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Baseball.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? mostly play house.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was formed, its purpose, its members, etc.

19. What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

21. What games did boys play in summer (rattlesnake, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Baseball.

CHILDREN'S GAMES

What games did girls play in summer (rattlesnake, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Mostly play house.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   Fox hounds, shinny, snow fort, some skating.

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   Mostly card games.

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   Generally just the children - mothers were too busy with sewing, knitting, patching. My father did a lot of reading.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   Answered above.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
   They used to put strings on the outside arm of children and a child child would pretend they were driving horses; if they were lucky enough to have wood, the "horses" pulled it so the driver had a ride.

PIECES AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
   June 1907.

26. Who organized it?  
   The priest & church members.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   For the entire Community.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? Yes  
   If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   Ball games, foot races, horse races, pillow fights.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   There were tables set and a good meal served by the women.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   Potatoes, meat, baked beans, pickles, cake, pie, cookies, tea and coffee.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? Started about 10:30 a.m. and lasted till dark, then a dance till about 2 a.m.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 
   Generally, only snowballing was done.

23. Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.
   Generally, just the children - nothing was too busy with sewing, knitting, patching. My father did a lot of gardening.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, egrets or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.
   They used to put strings on the outside arm. If someone stole a white object, they would hunt by every tree, bush, fence, they were lucky enough to have what we called "snowballs" as the answer above.

25. Was there much time for games; or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.
   PICNICS AND SPORTS

26. Give year and month if possible. June 1917
   Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? For the entire Community

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?
   If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?
   Picnic

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?
   There were tables set and a good meal served by the women.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?
   Cake, meat, baked beans, pickles, cake, pie, crackers, tea and coffee.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
   Started about 10:30 a.m. and lasted till dark, then a dance till about 2 a.m.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

The mammoth hats worn by the ladies—thin long skirts, the weapons drawn by oxen or horses with a number of little heads showing above the wagon box. The unloading of the boxes of food brought for the meal, the refreshment booth with its ice cream, candy, orange, lemonade in a big barrel, etc., etc.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

I knew only the large church picnics, but all through the country there were picnics held during the summer.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

1907 to about 1912 horse races were much in evidence, then they seemed to lose their appeal although they never completely died out. The fast paced running, obstacle races, etc., gradually fell out too. Baseball has been the main attraction.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

The men took part in racing, jumping, horse shoe games. The women were generally busy with serving meals or looking after small children. In addition, there was a small boys' baseball team scheduled to play a similar team from Lanigan at our picnic in 1969. These country children practiced with homemade balls made from willows.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Baseball.

What year? About 1909. How long did it continue? Right up to today.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

There was a small boys' baseball team scheduled to play a similar team from Lanigan at our picnic in 1969. These country children practiced with homemade balls made from willows.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

32. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you know of. In the early days, there were such things as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnic, family picnic, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drinks, when held, etc.

I knew only the large church picnic, but all through the country they were picnics held during the summer.

33. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

About 1912, there was a new trend in picnics. They were more elaborate and included more activities. Picnics became more social events rather than just eating.

34. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, namely young people.

The men took part in racing, jumping, three-legged races, etc. Women mostly played softball and basketball.

35. For what game was the first team organized in your community? Against whom?

What year? About 1910

How long did it continue? Right up to today.

36. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played in competitions in larger centers, etc.

There was a small boys' baseball team organized in 1910. They practiced with home-made balls and played against teams from the town.

Robert Burns.
The Holy Bible.

MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? None.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Violins.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

2 old violins in 1931 & 32.
Guitar in 1942.
Banjo in 1946.
Mandolin in 1948.
Piano in 1953.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

Singing was our main interest whenever a group gathered. Even at the dances if a good singer was present he was called upon after the in the community. (Were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

There were numerous concerts including singing, acting and recitations.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

Nellie Gray, The Baggage Coach Ate, Redwing,
Silver Bell Old Black Joe, Tennessee Wine, Old Kentucky
Home, Casey Jones, A Little Too Small.
Old Mother Bitchless Bald-headed End of the Broom,
A Little Too Small, The Maple Leaf Forever, Mother
Mechree, Marching 2nd Georgia.

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

The Irish songs had a special place when the Irish neighbor gathered but at other times a more general selection were sung.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

The town of Lanigen had a band around the year of 1910, but it was 12 miles distant so can't say much about its organization. I only remember it sounded heavenly on fair day.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Music is still appreciated— but the radio has changed the picture. Now we absorb it. In pioneer days we produced it by our own efforts.

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? 

Yes.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

Only in memory.
